paragraphs.text: %md
%md

%md

# Alpenglow Alpenglow is a free and open source C++ based Python recommender framework. We are going to use it train a matrix factorization model using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and evaluate the trained model using the normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG) metric. This experiment is impemented in Python

msg.data:
Alpenglow

Alpenglow is a free and open source C++ based Python recommender framework. We are going to use it train a matrix factorization model using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and evaluate the trained model using the normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG) metric.

This experiment is impemented in Python

paragraphs.title: Flink
paragraphs.text:
%md

# Apache Flink Flink is an open-source stream processing framework. We are going to use a factor model trained by asynchronous SGD, available as a pull request for Flink. The implementations uses a paramtere-server architecture for storing and accessing the model. This experiment is implemented in Scala.

msg.data:
Apache Flink

Flink is an open-source stream processing framework. We are going to use a factor model trained by asynchronous SGD, available as a pull request for Flink. The implementations uses a paramtere-server architecture for storing and accessing the model.

This experiment is implemented in Scala.

paragraphs.title: Spark
paragraphs.text:
%md

# Apache Spark Spark is an open-source engine for large-scale data processing. We are going to use the iALS implementation from Spark’s ML library, and provide ranking recommendations by reading the trained factor model to pandas. The experiment is implemented in Spark’s Python API, PySpark.

msg.data:
Apache Spark

Spark is an open-source engine for large-scale data processing. We are going to use the iALS implementation from Spark’s ML library, and provide ranking recommendations by reading the trained factor model to pandas.

The experiment is implemented in Spark’s Python API, PySpark.

%md 

### Warning!

Running all three kernels simultaneously requires quite a bit of system memory.

* If you have at least 16GB, you should be good to go.
* With 8GB, you should still be fine, but monitor your memory usage closely.
* Under 8GB, try running the notebook one kernel at a time.

paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import alpenglow as ag
from alpenglow.offline.models import FactorModel
from alpenglow.offline.evaluation import NdcgScore

%flink

import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.Utils._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.data.parsers._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.PSOfflineMatrixFactorization._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.sinks._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.PSTopKGeneratorWithLEMPForTutorial._

senv.setParallelism(4)

%spark.pyspark

from pyspark.mllib.recommendation import ALS, MatrixFactorizationModel, Rating
import pandas as pd
import shutil
import pyarrow.parquet as pq

paragraphs.title: reading data
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Reading the data

train_batch = pd.read_csv(
    'train_batch',
    header=None,
    names=['time','user','item']
)

%flink

val trainFile = "train_batch"
val testFile = "test_batch"
val modelFile = "model"

val trainData = ImplicitDataToRatingParser.parse(senv,trainFile,",",1,2)

msg.data:
trainFile: String = train_batch
testFile: String = test_batch
modelFile: String = model
trainData: hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.utils.DataStreamWithNameableFunctions[hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.Utils.Rating] = hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.utils.DataStreamWithNameableFunctions@7dabeca9

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

train = sc.textFile("train_batch")\
    .map(lambda l: l.split(','))\
    .map(lambda l: Rating(int(l[1]), int(l[2]), 1.0))

paragraphs.title: training models
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Training models

model = FactorModel(
    dimension=20,
    learning_rate=0.05,
    negative_rate=9,
    number_of_iterations=4,
)
model.fit(train_batch)

%flink

psOfflineMF(
        trainData,
        learningRate = 0.05,
        negativeSampleRate = 9,
        iterations = 4)
    .addSink(new VectorModelToFileSink(modelFile))
    .setParallelism(1)

senv.execute()

%spark.pyspark

rank = 20
numIter = 8
reg = 0.01
alpha = 40

model = ALS.trainImplicit(train, rank, numIter, reg, alpha)

paragraphs.title: calculating toplists
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Calculating toplists

test_batch = pd.read_csv(
    'test_batch',
    header=None,
    names=['time','user','item']
)
train_test_users = list(set(train_batch.user) & set(test_batch.user))
pd.Series(train_test_users).to_csv('train_test_users.csv',index=False)

alpenglow_topks = model.recommend(train_test_users, k=100)

%flink

val users = senv.readTextFile("train_test_users.csv")
val usersForToplist = users.map((x:String) => Rating(x.toInt,0,0,0))
val modelStream = VectorModelFileParser.parse(senv, modelFile, numFactors = 10)

psTopKGenerator(
        usersForToplist,
        model = modelStream)
    .addSink(new TopKToFileSink("flink_topks.csv"))
    .setParallelism(1)

senv.execute()

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# saving the model from spark

try:
    shutil.rmtree('spark_model')
except FileNotFoundError:
    pass
model.save(sc, "spark_model")

# loading the model to pandas dataframes

def read_factors(filename, colname):
    vectors = pq.read_table(filename).to_pandas()
    vectors.columns = [colname,'factors']
    vectors = pd.concat([ vectors[colname], vectors['factors'].apply(pd.Series) ], axis=1) 
    return vectors

user_vectors = read_factors("spark_model/data/user", "user")
item_vectors = read_factors("spark_model/data/product", "item")
item_vectors.set_index('item', inplace=True)

# preparing topk generation

train_batch = pd.read_csv('train_batch', header=None, names=['time','user','item'])
test_batch = pd.read_csv('test_batch', header=None, names=['time','user','item'])
train_test_users = set(train_batch.user) & set(test_batch.user)
relevant_user_vectors = user_vectors[user_vectors.user.isin(train_test_users)]

#calculating the toplists using pandas

user_toplists = []

for v in relevant_user_vectors.values:
    user = v[0]
    user_vec = pd.Series(v[1:])
    items = item_vectors\
        .multiply(user_vec,axis=1)\
        .sum(axis=1)\
        .nlargest(100)\
        .index

    for item,rank in zip(items, range(1,101)):
    	user_toplists.append((user,item,rank))

#saving the toplists to csv, to be read by the python kernel

spark_topks = pd.DataFrame.from_records(user_toplists, columns=['user','item','rank'])
spark_topks.to_csv('spark_topks.csv', index=False)

%md

# Evaluating toplists using Alpenglow

paragraphs.title: evaluating toplists using Alpenglow
paragraphs.text:
flink_topks = pd.read_csv('flink_topks.csv', header=None, names=['user','item','rank'])
spark_topks = pd.read_csv('spark_topks.csv')

test_relevant = test_batch[test_batch.user.isin(train_batch.user)]
test_relevant['score']=1

scores = [NdcgScore(test_relevant, topks) for topks in [alpenglow_topks, flink_topks, spark_topks]]
x=[1,2,3]
plt.bar(x, scores)
plt.title('Experiment scores')
plt.ylabel('Average NDCG')
plt.xticks(x, ['Alpenglow','Flink','Spark'])
plt.show()
